awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Collaborative Proposal: Diversifying Paths through Engineering with Extra-/Co-Curricular Participation
awd_abstract_narration:
While most current research in teaching and learning is performed in the classroom, evidence suggests that the quality of a student's learning is also affected by experiences outside of the classroom (i.e. extra-/co-curricular experiences). Engineering students in particular have available to them a rich variety of learning opportunities outside of the classroom - such as competition teams, undergraduate research experiences, and service learning organizations - which reinforce and strengthen the knowledge they gain through engineering coursework. The goal of this project is to determine the impact of engineering students' participation in extra-/co-curricular activities on their development into professional engineers. Understanding the specific benefits that engineering-focused extra-/co-curricular programs offer to students will allow those in career and academic advising positions to provide targeted advice to students on how to personalize their pathways through college engineering program, focusing on topics that are interesting to them and finding avenues for strengthening existing skills or learning new ones. The extra-/co-curricular setting also gives students a relaxed, enjoyable opportunity to practice engineering skills in an authentic environment, leading to improved confidence - a feature that is particularly important for students from underrepresented groups in engineering - and a more technically competent engineering workforce. Further, although certain features of the engineering-focused extra-/co-curricular experience may be challenging to reproduce in a classroom setting, other features may provide inspiration for alterative teaching practices which can enhance learning within the classroom.

This project answers two fundamental research questions: (1) What specific features of students' academic and professional development are affected by engineering-focused extra-/co-curricular participation, and (2) What specific features of extra-/co-curricular activities most influence students' academic and professional development' The research has a two-phased design where the first phase implements  the Statics Concept Inventory, the Engineering Professional Skills Assessment, and a self-efficacy survey  to measure achievement of learning outcomes including  mastery of fundamental engineering concepts, development of professional skills, and self-efficacy. In the second phase, participants from Phase 1 are recruited for interviews in order to uncover possible explanations for the research findings in Phase 1. The approach used in this work will lay the groundwork for other scholars in non-engineering disciplines to perform assessments of their own discipline-specific extra-/co-curricular activities to determine if similar patterns exist. The framework used in this research will also allow other scholars to explore factors related to engineering-focused extra-/co-curricular participation which are not covered in this research, for example, determining how the extra-/co-curricular experience uniquely affects engineering students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research in teaching and learning largely focuses on practices and activities that occur in the classroom, but evidence suggests that the quality of a student’s learning is defined by a combination of experiences both inside and outside of the classroom (Terenzini, Pascarella, and Blimling, 1990). Engineering students in particular benefit from a rich variety of extra- and co-curricular options that specifically aid in their professional formation. Students in engineering programs commonly intern for engineering companies, compete in engineering-related challenges, design devices to serve the needs of a person or community, or research an engineering problem, all of which reinforce and strengthen the knowledge they gain through engineering coursework. This project aimed to determine the impact of participation in engineering-focused extra- and co-curricular activities – specifically, internships and co-ops, competition teams, undergraduate research, and service learning organizations – on students’ learning, development of professional skills, and self-efficacy.

 

Our results demonstrated that students who had participated in any engineering-focused extra-/co-curricular activity had a higher mean in each of the items from the self-efficacy survey and the cumulative standard deviation is lower for these groups as well.  The results are consistent with previous research about the impact of extra-/co-curricular activities on students’ academic achievements and their confidence in their capability to perform an activity. Such results suggest that engineering students’ engagement in engineering extra-/co-curricular activities enhances academic skills reinforcing and strengthening the knowledge they gain through engineering coursework. Additionally, engagement in these types of activities also enhances engineering skills critical for their professional formation.  Based on these results, we can reinforce the importance of providing engineering students with the guidance necessary to choose extra-/co-curricular activities to enhance their learning and strengthen engineering skills while improving their confidence in their academic and professional capabilities.  

Throughout the project, we also had methodological learnings related to the survey and engineering professional skills assessment (EPSA) instruments we used.  We administered the survey to Virginia Tech and Rose-Hulman Mechanical Engineering students (both participants and non-participants in engineering-focused extra-/co-curricular activities). After analyzing the data, we found we had to revise and reimplement the survey, changing the order of some of the sections to secure more complete responses (move demographic information earlier and concept inventory later).  The second deployment of the survey was more successful.  We conducted the EPSA at Virginia Tech though the groups were small.  We identified some process improvements for future implementations.  For example, we learned that the composition of the group in terms of grade level (third or fourth year) and internship experiences can impact group interactions and EPSA measurement outcomes.  Future EPSA implementations might consider asking some clarifying questions to understand background knowledge and experiences before creating groups.

The COVID19 pandemic had particular consequences on this research as our our research methods and the subject of our study are entirely driven by student involvement.  Nevertheless, this project yielded meaningful results regarding the role of extra-/co-curricular activities in enhancing student’s learning and strengthening engineering skills while improving their confidence in their academic and professional capabilities. We also generated knowledge useful to the broader engineering community regarding improving the research methods and tools used.
